items.title: Generative Behaviors as Key Targets for Cognitive Models
items.author: Judith E. FanDepartment of Psychology, Stanford University
items.content: <article>Current Directions in Psychological Science, Ahead of Print. Human behavior is fundamentally generative: People create pictures, write stories, compose music, and engage in conversation. Traditional approaches in psychology and cognitive science have not focused on this open-endedness, instead favoring more ...</article>

items.title: From a Baby’s Point of View: How Infants’ Face Diets Shape Their Face Perception
items.author: Charisse B. Pickron, Laurie Bayet
items.content: <article>Current Directions in Psychological Science, Ahead of Print. Individual variations in face-perception expertise become apparent by the second year of life. We propose that infants’ “face diet”—the nature and quantity of their visual interactions with faces—provides a useful lens for understanding how individual ...</article>

items.title: Using Artificial Intelligence to Better Understand Human Intelligence
items.author: Gordon Pennycook, Thomas H. Costello, David G. Rand
items.content: <article>Current Directions in Psychological Science, Ahead of Print. A consistent pattern emerges from the history of psychology: Technological advances change the way that we understand ourselves. We argue that, in addition to various uses that are already common (e.g., qualitative coding), large language models can be ...</article>

items.title: Understanding, Predicting, and Preventing Suicide: Recent Advances Using Digital and Computational Methods
items.author: Matthew K. Nock, Shirley B. Wang
items.content: <article>Current Directions in Psychological Science, Ahead of Print. Suicide is among the most perplexing of all human behaviors. It has been a leading cause of death for decades, and despite significant study it continues unabated. Over the past few years, the development of new digital and computational methods has ...</article>
